Problem:
Consider a system modeled by the complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t}x(t) \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant and \\( x(t) \\) satisfies the differential equation \\( \dot{x} = Dx \\) with D being a constant matrix. The transformation applied is \\( f(x) = Ux \\) at time t = 0, where U is a unitary matrix.

After observing \\( x(t) \\) at t = T, can we uniquely determine the original vector \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0 without knowing whether \\( f(x) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without the knowledge of the application of \\( f(x) \\), it is uncertain whether the transformation U was applied, resulting in different potential initial vectors \\( x_0 \\). The evolution under \\( \dot{x} = Dx \\) alone would not be sufficient to backtrack to the unique original state without this knowledge.

causal_map_integration: The state of x(t) at any time t depends on the initial state x(0) through the differential equation. The transformation f(x) applied at t=0 affects x(t). The parameter D governs the evolution of x(t). The value of ω influences z(t) but does not directly affect x(t). Knowing x(t) at t=T allows us to infer x(0) up to a unitary transformation if f(x) was applied.
